Malta star thistle seems to be increasing in number over the years.  Homeowner has been trying to pull it up and burn the plants.  Hopes to get a handle on it soon.  Located off HIghway 39 about 10 miles west of Hunt, Texas.

In drainage to culvert at westernmost entrance to parking lot for softball fields, opposite entrance to off-leash area. Dozens of individual plants in this location. Although I quickly identified the plant as a potential invasive species, it took a great deal of research to identify the species.

In right-of-way on east side of I-35, between main lane and northbound service road, between Little Walnut Creek and entrance ramp between US 183 and Rundberg Lane. Because getting photos at this location is dangerous, photo shown is of plants in Walnut Creek Metropolitan Park. Identification is certain: plants were seen up close at speed below 10 mph.

Scattered throughout the right-of-way on the east side of I-35 south of Parmer Lane. (Photo is of a patch in Walnut Creek Metropolitan Park because it's not easy to safely get a photo at this site. But the distinct yellow blossoms were also showing here.)
Scattered throughout this embankment between the northbound main lanes of I-35 and the service road. (Photo is from another site because of the hazards of getting a picture at this location.)
